title: Quiz 5: Special Populations & Conditions
description: Comprehensive review of Eating Disorders, Somatic Symptom Disorders, Neurodevelopmental Disorders (ADHD/Autism), Disruptive Behavior, and Cognitive Disorders (Dementia/Delirium).

questions.question: Match the Eating Disorder with its primary characteristics:

pairs.right: Refusal to maintain normal weight, intense fear of fat
Binge eating followed by purging; usually normal weight
Recurrent binge eating without compensatory purging

questions.explanation: Anorexia is defined by low weight. Bulimia involves purging. Pica is eating non-foods. Binge Eating Disorder lacks the purging element.
questions.hint: Anorexia involves restriction; Bulimia involves compensation.

questions.question: Review the table below comparing Delirium and Dementia. Which statement accurately describes DELIRIUM?

richContent.content:
FeatureDeliriumDementia
OnsetRapidGradual
DurationBriefProgressive
ConsciousnessImpaired/FluctuatingIntact

options.text: It is a chronic, progressive condition
It involves an acute, fluctuating disturbance of consciousness
Memory loss is the only symptom
It is a normal part of aging

questions.explanation: Delirium is an acute, reversible syndrome involving disturbance of consciousness and cognition. It often has an underlying medical cause (infection, toxicity). Dementia is chronic and progressive.

questions.question: Which of the following are common symptoms of Attention-Deficit/Hyperactivity Disorder (ADHD)? (Select all that apply)
questions.explanation: The core triad of ADHD is inattention, hyperactivity, and impulsivity. Hallucinations are psychotic symptoms.
questions.hint: Think of the name of the disorder itself.

questions.question: A client with Somatic Symptom Disorder gains 'Secondary Gain' from their illness. What does this mean?

options.text: External benefits like attention or avoiding responsibilities

questions.explanation: Primary gain is the internal relief of anxiety. Secondary gain involves external benefits, such as getting attention, being excused from work, or avoiding difficult situations.
questions.hint: It's the 'extra' benefit they get from others.

questions.question: Conduct Disorder in childhood is a precursor to Antisocial Personality Disorder in adulthood.
questions.explanation: Conduct disorder involves violation of rights and societal norms. If these behaviors persist into adulthood (after age 18), the diagnosis often shifts to Antisocial Personality Disorder.
questions.hint: Think about the progression of rule-breaking behavior.

questions.question: The inability to recognize or name objects despite intact sensory abilities, often seen in dementia, is called ___BLANK___.
questions.explanation: Agnosia is the loss of ability to recognize objects, faces, voices, or places. Apraxia is the inability to execute motor functions. Aphasia is language deterioration.
questions.hint: It starts with 'A' and means 'not knowing'.

questions.question: Which medication class is considered the first line of treatment for ADHD?
questions.explanation: Stimulants like Methylphenidate (Ritalin) and Amphetamines are the most effective and common treatment for ADHD. They help filter distractions.
questions.hint: Paradoxically, these drugs 'stimulate' the focus centers.

questions.question: What is the term for the fabrication of symptoms or self-infliction of injury to assume the sick role (formerly Munchausen Syndrome)?
questions.explanation: Factitious Disorder involves the intentional production of physical or psychological signs to gain attention or assume the sick role, unlike malingering which is for material gain.

questions.question: Which intervention is most appropriate for a client with Dementia who is experiencing 'confabulation'?

options.text: Isolate the client to prevent embarrassment

questions.explanation: Confabulation is the unconscious filling of memory gaps. It is not lying. Confrontation causes anxiety. Validation or distraction respects the client's dignity while managing the behavior.
questions.hint: Do not argue; validate the emotion instead.

questions.question: Which of the following are physical complications associated with Anorexia Nervosa? (Select all that apply)
questions.explanation: Starvation leads to the body shutting down non-essential functions (amenorrhea), trying to keep warm (lanugo), slowing the heart (bradycardia), and dangerous electrolyte shifts.
questions.hint: Think about the body's response to starvation.
